turns.text: The Latin American situation in - the last development I know of was the military and financial assistance Columbia --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: -- for the for the drug uh control And I support that fully Im not sure we have the right solution to it but at least were were going to the source of the problem And
the source of supply Uh the problem is here but the source of supply is there
In fact I think lot of the - Ive been to uh Peru several times
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Ive never been to other parts of South America but uh I have been to Peru and they need some assistance down there and Im sure that uh as an undeveloped country they look look for it but there is not exactly lot of uh physical responsibility there listen probably fiscal not physical
turns.label: sd

turns.text: And I I think that uh they need guidance and assistance but they need to learn how to stand on their own own two feet also
turns.label: sv

turns.text: I agree I think that for so long power financially uh governmentally every which way was in the hands of such few --
turns.label: aa

turns.text: -- that theres not the middle class that we we perceive
Oh no the and the poor are extremely poor I know -
turns.label: sv

turns.text: I know uh some of the areas in in Texas seem poor but until youve seen some of those uh native
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Latin Americans come down from the hills you cant imagine what poor is And uh the worst scene Ive ever had I think was uh someone eating out of out of garbage can on the streets in Lima Peru
And and just very happy to get that
turns.label: bf

turns.text: I have brother who spent two years in Bolivia
turns.label: sd

turns.text: And this is very much his you know reaction that the rich are so rich and the poor are so poor
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Oh the theres joke the the graft and the uh payoffs down there are are an accepted way and in way -
turns.label: sd

turns.text: And theres theres sad joke I guess all jokes are really sad but theres joke about the uh Ambassador from Latin America that came to visit Senator in the and was taken to his home for dinner and the uh home was palatial They had five or six servants you know and and lot of expensive uh holdings and all that and the Ambassador said but I know what you make as Senator how can you afford all of this And he said come Ill show you and he walked out in the backyard and the uh Senator said do you see that hospital over there And the Ambassador said yes And he patted his pocket and he said fifteen percent He said you see that school over there And the Ambassador said yes and he pot patted his pocket and said fifteen percent so -
turns.label: sv

turns.text: so the next year the Senator went to Latin America to visit the Ambassador and was treated to dinner in his home and it was twice as large and four times as many servants He said well I know how poor your country is how can you afford this uh in such poor country and he he said come Ill show you and he walked out the backyard and he said do you see that hospital over there And the Senator looked and he couldnt see anything he said no And the Ambassador potted patted his pocket and said one hundred percent so -
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Yeah that - its sad story but -
turns.label: b

turns.text: Yes yes but it uh it is problem
turns.label: aa

turns.text: I know Uh I have sister-in-law who is from Nicaragua and her family - her father was fairly uh high ranking official under Somoza And when that went down the tubes they had to get out
turns.label: aa

turns.text: filtered through into into America through Guatamala through Mexico through Honduras you know two here three there one here you know this kind of thing until -
and now uh couple of the older ones stayed or went back but the rest of them now have their American citizenship and are leading productive lives
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Well the oth- the other instance I think of their inability to to handle things the cholera
turns.label: sd

turns.text: and hepatitis epidemics now in in Latin America And it shows the the unpreparedness for such such problem
Oh the stories she tells you know are just unnerving --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: And theyre theyre so rich in resources there Theyre very rich in oil and gas And theyre very rich in gold and silver and very rich in in uh natural resources such as the fish and uh --
turns.label: sd

turns.text: -- timber and and copper and all types of uh resources but they -
Yes and - but they dont have - its sort of like Russia they dont have the ability to develop it
turns.label: aa

turns.text: Well - and you know theyre very willing to be taught in many cases now too but you know theres just always this kind of resentment underlying I think that when they receive help from us they want it but they dont want it I mean
turns.label: b

turns.text: uh-huh It its sort of illustrated by the uh World Bank and International Monetary Fund not wanting to continue to do business there because they offer assistance then dont get repaid
turns.label: aa

turns.text: So its sort of thumbing of the nose uh approach They need it and they need to live up to certain regulations and expectations but uh then dont Of course its very volatile government uh situation too
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Well - and I think that you know it - somewhat sarcastic view - but some of those drugs czars you know - they they know that by pumping that poison into our system --
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- that thats the way to bring us to our knees more on their level
You know thats really uh kind of far fetched idea I know and I dont think people probably think those things consciously
turns.label: sv

turns.text: but its like in any sibling rivalry --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: The solution discussed at one time and I think it has real merit on the drug situation is that the - the government could spend less money by buying the crop and destroying it than they are in trying to to beef up the military and to do all other things I think it would be cheaper to buy it and destroy it which would still give the uh the grower in Columbia and elsewhere in Latin America the uh the money that they apparently need and go go to the illegal crop for And it would save the money in --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: -- in the long run in how much theyre trying to do
And in the short run probably too
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Course then could you know at at some point could you ever convince someone to turn around and grow something that was productive for humankind
turns.label: qy

turns.text: And I I think finding an alternate to that would be very good
turns.label: sv

turns.text: I mean even their even their legal crops are things that we dont perceive as being healthy now from medical standpoint of view coffee --
turns.label: sv

turns.text: Theyre certainly legal but theyre certainly not healthy
turns.label: sd

turns.text: Well have we come up with solution yet Salina
turns.label: qy

turns.text: No not that I know of But its been fun hashing about it I suppose At any rate - yeah
turns.label: nn

turns.text: Yeah yeah Well one of these days uh I hope well find some some way to substitute the good crops for illegal ones
turns.label: b^m

turns.text: Well lets just hope that the powers that be uh have time to little bit once in while to to think in some farther reaching avenues than you and I do here tonight but -
turns.label: sv

turns.label: fc
